objectives: Define and differentiate between homophones, homographs, and homonyms
Identify these types of words in sentences
Use context to understand the correct meaning and spelling of these words
Avoid common errors in writing and speaking related to these words

sections.text: Homophones are words that sound the same when you say them, but they have different meanings and different spellings. The word 'homophone' comes from Greek words: 'homo' (meaning same) and 'phone' (meaning sound). Remembering 'phone' can help you remember that these words sound the same.

examples.label: to / too / two
examples.value: I am going to the village. My brother is coming too. We will see two temples there.

examples.label: their / there / they're
examples.value: They're going to their house over there.

examples.label: see / sea
examples.value: From the hill, you can see the deep blue sea.

examples.label: write / right
examples.value: Please write the right answer in your notebook.

examples.label: son / sun
examples.value: The farmer and his son worked in the fields under the hot sun.

examples.label: ate / eight
examples.value: He ate eight mangoes from the basket.

examples.label: buy / by / bye
examples.value: I will go by the shop to buy some milk, then I'll say bye.

examples.label: know / no
examples.value: I know there is no water left in the pot.

examples.label: weak / week
examples.value: After being sick for a week, he felt very weak.

examples.label: hear / here
examples.value: Please come here; I can't hear you.

examples.label: flour / flower
examples.value: My mother used flour to make bread and put a flower in the vase.

examples.label: bare / bear
examples.value: It is not safe to walk with bare feet in a forest where a bear might live.

examples.label: cell / sell
examples.value: The prisoner was in a dark cell. The farmer wants to sell his crops.

examples.label: our / hour
examples.value: We waited for an hour for our bus to arrive.

examples.label: pair / pear
examples.value: She bought a pair of shoes and a juicy pear from the market.

examples.label: which / witch
examples.value: Which road leads to the haunted house where the witch lives?

examples.label: wait / weight
examples.value: You will have to wait your turn. / The weight of this sack is too much for me.

examples.label: peace / piece
examples.value: Everyone hopes for peace in the world. / Can I have another piece of cake?

examples.label: for / four
examples.value: This gift is for you. / There are four people in my family.

examples.label: road / rode
examples.value: The main road is very busy. / He rode his bicycle to school yesterday.

examples.label: tale / tail
examples.value: My grandfather tells a wonderful tale about the king. / A monkey has a long tail.

examples.label: stair / stare
examples.value: Be careful on that broken stair. / It is not polite to stare at people.

examples.label: plain / plane
examples.value: The message was written in plain language. / The plane flew high above the clouds.

examples.label: mail / male
examples.value: Did you receive any mail today? / The male lion has a large mane.

examples.label: waist / waste
examples.value: He tied a belt around his waist. / We should not waste food or water.

examples.label: meat / meet
examples.value: Many people do not eat meat on Tuesdays. / Let's meet at the temple in the evening.

examples.label: allowed / aloud
examples.value: You are not allowed to talk in the library. / Please read the poem aloud.

examples.label: some / sum
examples.value: I need some help with this difficult math sum.

examples.label: weather / whether
examples.value: I don't know whether the weather will be good for the match.

examples.label: dear / deer
examples.value: My dear friend, I saw a beautiful deer in the forest today.

sections.text: Homographs are words that are spelled the same, but they have different meanings and may have different pronunciations. The word 'homograph' comes from Greek words: 'homo' (meaning same) and 'graph' (meaning writing). Remembering 'graph' can help you remember that these words have the same spelling.

examples.label: lead (leed) / lead (led)
examples.value: He will lead the team. / The pipe is made of lead, which is a heavy metal.

examples.label: wind (wɪnd) / wind (waɪnd)
examples.value: The wind is blowing strongly. / You need to wind the clock.

examples.label: bow (baʊ) / bow (boʊ)
examples.value: You should bow to the king. / He used a bow and arrow to hunt.

examples.label: minute (mɪnɪt) / minute (maɪˈnjuːt)
examples.value: Please wait for one minute. / The details were so minute, they were hard to see.

examples.label: tear (teer) / tear (tair)
examples.value: A tear rolled down her cheek. / Be careful not to tear the page.

examples.label: desert (dɪˈzɜːrt) / desert (ˈdɛzərt)
examples.value: He decided to desert his old village. / The camel is a useful animal in the desert.

examples.label: live (lɪv) / live (laɪv)
examples.value: We live in a small village. / The cricket match was a live broadcast.

examples.label: bat / bat
examples.value: A bat is a mammal that can fly. / He hit the ball with a cricket bat.

examples.label: well / well
examples.value: She does not feel well today. / We get water from the village well.

examples.label: ring / ring
examples.value: The phone started to ring. / She wore a beautiful gold ring on her finger.

examples.label: watch / watch
examples.value: I like to watch the stars at night. / My father gave me a new watch for my birthday.

examples.label: fly / fly
examples.value: A fly was buzzing near the food. / The birds fly high in the sky.

examples.label: left / left
examples.value: Turn left at the next corner. / He left the house early in the morning.

examples.label: rose / rose
examples.value: The rose is a beautiful flower. / The sun rose at 6 AM.

examples.label: light / light
examples.value: The bag was very light. / Please turn on the light; it's dark in here.

examples.label: close (klos) / close (kloz)
examples.value: My house is close to the school. / Please close the door when you leave.

examples.label: object (əbˈdʒɛkt) / object (ˈɒbdʒɪkt)
examples.value: I object to your decision. / The police found a strange object at the scene.

examples.label: present (prɪˈzɛnt) / present (ˈprɛzənt)
examples.value: The teacher will present the award. / I received a lovely present for my birthday.

examples.label: row (roʊ) / row (raʊ)
examples.value: We sat in the front row. / The two brothers had a loud row (argument).

examples.label: produce (prəˈdjuːs) / produce (ˈprɒdjuːs)
examples.value: Our farm can produce many vegetables. / We sell fresh produce at the market.

examples.label: subject (səbˈdʒɛkt) / subject (ˈsʌbdʒɪkt)
examples.value: The king can subject his people to new laws. / My favorite subject is Science.

examples.label: contract (kənˈtrækt) / contract (ˈkɒntrækt)
examples.value: When you get cold, your muscles contract. / He signed a five-year contract for the job.

examples.label: content (kənˈtɛnt) / content (ˈkɒntɛnt)
examples.value: He was content with his simple life in the village. / What is the content of this box?

examples.label: sewer (so-er) / sewer (soo-er)
examples.value: A sewer is a person who sews. / The city's sewer system needs to be cleaned.

examples.label: entrance (ɪnˈtrɑːns) / entrance (ˈɛntrəns)
examples.value: The beautiful music will entrance the audience. / Please use the main entrance to the building.

sections.text: Homonyms are words that are spelled the same AND sound the same, but have different meanings. These are the trickiest of the three. A homonym is both a homophone (same sound) and a homograph (same spelling). The word 'homonym' comes from 'homo' (same) and 'nym' (name).

examples.label: bat / bat
examples.value: The cricket bat broke during the match. / At night, a bat flew into our house.

examples.label: address / address
examples.value: What is your home address? / The village head will address the crowd.

examples.label: ring / ring
examples.value: The school bell will ring soon. / My mother lost her wedding ring.

examples.label: right / right
examples.value: You are right; we should take the right turn.

examples.label: well / well
examples.value: I hope you are feeling well. / The old well has very sweet water.

examples.label: match / match
examples.value: He lit a match to start the fire. / Our village team won the kabaddi match.

examples.label: rock / rock
examples.value: He sat on a large rock by the river. / My brother loves to listen to rock music.

examples.label: fly / fly
examples.value: Let's fly a kite. / Don't let that fly sit on your food.

examples.label: trip / trip
examples.value: Our school planned a trip to the city. / Be careful not to trip over that stone.

examples.label: letter / letter
examples.value: I wrote a letter to my friend. / 'A' is the first letter of the alphabet.

examples.label: can / can
examples.value: I can lift this box. / Please give me a can of juice.

examples.label: bank / bank
examples.value: We sat on the bank of the river. / I need to go to the bank to get some money.

examples.label: watch / watch
examples.value: He wears a new watch. / Did you watch the movie yesterday?

examples.label: mean / mean
examples.value: What does this word mean? / The cruel man was very mean to the animals.

examples.label: pen / pen
examples.value: I need a new pen to write my exam. / The farmer kept the sheep in a pen.

examples.label: bark / bark
examples.value: The dog's bark woke me up. / The bark of the neem tree is used in medicine.

examples.label: fair / fair
examples.value: We all went to the village fair. / A good leader must be fair to everyone.

examples.label: leaves / leaves
examples.value: The tree sheds its leaves in autumn. / My father leaves for work at 8 AM.

examples.label: park / park
examples.value: The children are playing in the park. / You cannot park your tractor here.

examples.label: spring / spring
examples.value: Flowers bloom in the spring season. / The old mattress has a broken spring.

examples.label: ruler / ruler
examples.value: Ashoka was a great ruler. / Use a ruler to draw a straight line.

examples.label: tire / tire
examples.value: The long walk will tire you. / The cycle has a flat tire.

examples.label: crane / crane
examples.value: A crane is a tall bird. / A large crane was used to lift the fallen tree.

examples.label: pound / pound
examples.value: You need one pound of sugar for this cake. / Please don't pound on the table.

examples.label: wave / wave
examples.value: She gave a friendly wave as the bus left. / A huge wave crashed on the shore.

examples.label: lie / lie
examples.value: You should not tell a lie. / I need to lie down because I am tired.

examples.label: bright / bright
examples.value: The sun is very bright today. / She is a very bright student.

examples.label: cool / cool
examples.value: The weather is nice and cool today. / He thinks he is very cool.

examples.label: kind / kind
examples.value: He is a very kind man. / What kind of fruit is this?

examples.label: saw / saw
examples.value: I saw a big snake yesterday. / The carpenter used a saw to cut the wood.

sections.text: It can be confusing to remember the difference between these three types of words. Here are some simple tips to help you.
usage_examples: Tip 1: Break down the words. Remember the Greek roots: 'phone' means sound, 'graph' means writing, and 'nym' means name.
Tip 2: Homo-PHONE = Same SOUND. They sound the same, but spelling is different (e.g., hear/here).
Tip 3: Homo-GRAPH = Same WRITING (spelling). They are spelled the same, but the meaning is different. Pronunciation can be the same or different (e.g., bat/bat, lead/lead).
Tip 4: Homo-NYM = Same NAME. They have the same spelling AND the same sound, but different meanings (e.g., bank/bank). All homonyms are also homographs and homophones.

Tip 5: Context is King! The only way to know the correct meaning and spelling of these words is to look at the other words in the sentence. The context will tell you if 'right' means a direction or the correct answer.
